titleStmt.title: Certaine queres concerning the Booke of common prayer, and divers other articles of religion: propounded to a reverend divine of the City of London, and his modest reply unto the same, for the satisfaction of tender consciences; wherein these particulars are fully resolved, viz. 1. Whether the Booke of common prayer is to bee allowed by Gods Word or no? 2. Whether articles of religion agreed upon by a synod bee binding by Gods Word or no? 3. Whether we be tyed by the Gospel to the order and use of the Apostles in all things for matters of religion or no? 4. Whether there bee any right ministry or ecclesiasticall governement at this time in the Church of England or no? 5. Whether nothing may be added in point of worship but what is axactly [sic] commanded in Scripture or no? 6. Whether the clergie are to have the whole governement of the Church in matters ecclesiasticall or no? ... 18. Lastly, whether the King and State be bound to observe the iudiciall lawes of Moses in the puuishment [sic] of criminall offences or no?

titleStmt.title: Certaine queres concerning the Booke of common prayer, and divers other articles of religion: propounded to a reverend divine of the City of London, and his modest reply unto the same, for the satisfaction of tender consciences; wherein these particulars are fully resolved, viz. 1. Whether the Booke of common prayer is to bee allowed by Gods Word or no? 2. Whether articles of religion agreed upon by a synod bee binding by Gods Word or no? 3. Whether we be tyed by the Gospel to the order and use of the Apostles in all things for matters of religion or no? 4. Whether there bee any right ministry or ecclesiasticall governement at this time in the Church of England or no? 5. Whether nothing may be added in point of worship but what is axactly [sic] commanded in Scripture or no? 6. Whether the clergie are to have the whole governement of the Church in matters ecclesiasticall or no? ... 18. Lastly, whether the King and State be bound to observe the iudiciall lawes of Moses in the puuishment [sic] of criminall offences or no?

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Church of England. -- Book of common prayer -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2012-06 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images

div.head: CERTAINE QVERES CONCERning the Booke of Common Prayer, and divers other Articles of Religion.
div.p: WHether the book intituled The booke of Common Prayer, allowed by publike authority in this Realme, is to be allowed in the Church of God, by Gods word or no?

An≈øwer. Before I give my an≈øwere to this demand I mu≈øt intreat you to ob≈øerve this my Prote≈øtation, that I have never as yet preached again≈øt the u≈øe of this booke of prayers: and in mine owne booke extant in print, I have once ≈øpoken openly, to the good allowance thereof.

Secondly I re≈øort to Common prayers, and ≈øometime being reque≈øted, I do according as it is pre≈øcribed, ≈øay the prayers. If notwith≈øtanding I ≈øhall be urged to ≈øpeake now, what I thinke, whereby I may ≈øeeme to be called to a forme of inqui≈øition, as there is no law by which God hath tyed me of duety to be my owne accu≈øer: ≈øo I be≈øeech you let this my an≈øwere rather witne≈ø≈øe my ≈øaithfulne≈ø≈øe to your demands, then be preiudiciall to my hurt and hinderance. Which thing as I mo≈øt humbly crave, ≈øo in per≈øwa≈øion of your favours, I will an≈øwere boldly wherein I am enquired.

Fir≈øt the ≈øimilitude that this booke hath with the forme of prayer, which the Papi≈øts u≈øed, I thinke declineth from the equity of tho≈øe lawes, Deut. 7. v. 25. The forma of the booke of common prayer. Deut. 12. v. 30. Deut. 18. ver. 9. Which thing our Fathers ≈øo much regarded in the primitive Church, that their bookes are full of great complaints, again≈øt all ≈øimilitude to be had with the Gentiles: yea the ≈øecond councell of Braecca, made at a decree, that no Chri≈øtian ≈øhould have either Bay-leafes, or greene Boughes in their hou≈øes becau≈øe the Gentiles ≈øo accu≈øtomed. And at this day all reformed Church in Fraunce, Polenia, Hel ‚Ä¢ itia Scotlande, and other places, have changed that forme of prayers. Which prudency of all ages, if we ≈øhall condemne, the rebuke of the Apo≈øtle. I thinke, will touch us, 1. Cor. 14. ver. 36. Came the word of God out from you or came it el≈øe unto you onely?

Secondarily, we have the P≈øalmes, Venite, Benedictus, Magnificat, Nure
dimittis, u≈øuall in our mini≈øtry, of which we can give no rea≈øon. Nor I ≈øee no cau≈øe why we ≈øhould more leave out the Aue Maria. And becau≈øe of patting the Scriptures againe into the Epi≈øtles and Go≈øpells (which was not heard of before the dayes of popery) I dare not avow that this is that reverent handling of the ≈øcripture and the right dividing of the word of truth, which S ‚Ä¢ int Paul requireth, 2. Tim. 2. ver. 15. Thirdly, the great inconveniency which hath followed this booke, while it hath maintained an unlearned Mini≈øtry, and made it thought ≈øufficient, to have the fervice read. Wherein we have made the ≈øpirit of God to ≈øpeake in vain. That the Mini≈øter of the Go≈øpell, must be no young ≈øcholler, but of nece≈ø≈øity mu≈øt be apt to teach. 1 Tim. 3. ve. 2. able to exhort with whole≈øome doctrine, and able to reproove them that ≈øpeake again≈øt i ‚Ä¢ . Tit. 1. ver. 9. This is another cau≈øe why I can not freely (as I would gladly) ≈øub≈øcribe unto the booke, that it hath all things allowable by the word of God. Some other particular thinges, the Bi≈øhops them≈øelves doe confe≈ø≈øe to be faulty.
2. Quere. Whether the Articles ≈øet downe by the Cleargy in a Synod, and allowed by authority, be according to Gods word or no?

An≈ø. I confe≈ø≈øe the Articles of faith and Sacraments (as I am per≈øwaded) are good. So I thinke of the Articles which are of traditions, of an Oath before a Iudge, of the civill Magi≈øtrate, of the Doctrine taught in the Homilies, &c. Onely that one, which is of con≈øecration of Arch-bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, I can by no meanes confe≈ø≈øe it godly, and according to the word of God.
3. Quere. Whether we be tyed by Gods word, to the order and u≈øe of the Apo≈øtles and primitive Church in all things, or no?

An≈ø. What≈øoever was the u≈øuall order of the Apo≈øtles, no doubt we are bound unto it, when Saint Paul had ≈øaid to Timothy: Thou ha≈øt knowne what I have u≈øed to doe, hee added ≈øtraightly, Continue in the things which thou ha≈øt learned, 2 Tim. 3. v. 14. And ≈øo he ≈øtraightly charged the Philippians, to have care to tho≈øe thinges which they had ≈øeene and heard in him Philip. 4. ver. 9.
4. Quere. Whether there be any right mini≈øtrie, or eccle≈øia≈øticall governement at this time in the Church of England, or no;

An≈øwere. If you meane right, hauing ≈øuch a calling as the word of God requireth, (of which reade 1. Timot. 3. ver. 2. Act. 1. ver. 23. Actes. 14. ver. 23 1. A right mini≈øterie Timot. 4 ver. 14.) I am ≈øure you will confe≈ø≈øe it is not right. If you meane a right mini≈øtration, as concerning Sacraments and doctrine, I humbly confe≈ø≈øe and thinke, that no man ought to ≈øeparate him ≈øelfe from the Church which God hath given us in this land. of regiment, read the ≈øeaventh Article.
5. Quere. Whether that nothing may be in the Church, either concerning ceremonies, or regiment, but that onely, which the Lord him ≈øelfe in his word commandeth, or no.

An≈øwere. Such ceremonies as do not nece≈ø≈øarily appertaine to the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt may be changed, ob≈øerving alwayes that which Saint Paul hath commanded, Philip. 4. ver. 8.1. Corint. 14. ver. 26.

Quere. Whether every particular Church or pari≈øh in this Realme of England, of nece≈ø≈øitie and by the order of Gods word, ought to have their Pa≈øtours
Elders, and Deacons, cho≈øen by the people of that their pari≈øh: and they onely to have the whole government of that Church in matters eccle≈øia≈øticall, or no.

An≈øwere. Where ≈øoever this government hath bin, the ehoyce hath bin by certaine, with the allowance of the people, for ought that ever I read. But what were mo≈øt requi≈øite for this pre≈øeut time, I leave it to tho≈øe whome God hath ≈øet in authoritie and at this time called for that purpo≈øe of the manner of chu≈øing I will not define: for the order to be had, it is manife≈øt in the Apo≈øtles time: and in the primitive Church it was the u≈øe. Neyther any, man I thinke, Elders ought to be in the church. will denie it. After long time in ≈øome places, this order cea≈øed, as Saint Ambro≈øe ≈øaith, Superbia Doctorum, qui ≈øoli volebant regere Eccle≈øiam &c. Ambro in 1 Tim. cap. 5. And therfore I think now there ought to be Elders as at the fir≈øt & as in Tertullians time, ut pra≈øidiant probati quidam Seniores, qui honorem i≈øtum non pretio ≈øed te≈øtimouio adipi≈øcantur, Tertull. Apolo. cap. 39.
7. Quere. Whether there is equalitie of all the Mini≈øters of this Realme, as well concerning government and juri≈ødiction as touching the mini≈øtration of the word and Sacraments.

An≈øwere. That all Mini≈øters are equally called to the preaching of the word and mini≈øterie of the Sacraments, no man I think will deny. As touching governement (≈øeeing the holy Gho≈øt calleth them fellow Mini≈øters, fellow Elders, fellow Officers, fellow Souldiers, fellow labourers, fellow ≈øervants: feing Saint Peter expre≈øly forbideth to exerci≈øe Dominion over the Lords heritage, 1. Pet. 5.3. ≈øeeing, Saint Iohn plainly condemneth the pride of Diotrophes, for chalenging a Lord≈øhip to command and excommunieate of his ≈øole authoritie, epi≈øt. 3. ver. 9.10. ≈øeing our Saviour Chri≈øt, the God of Glory, No ≈øuperioritie among Mini≈øters. & of the tribe of Iuda, neither him ≈øelfe would be a King. Iohn 6. ver. 15. And when his Di≈øciples did ≈øtrive for ≈øuperiority, he taught them plainly, that the people of the Nation they had Kings, and amonge≈øt them were rulers, which we called gratious Lords, but no ≈øuch dominion ≈øhould be in Mini≈øterie, Luc. 22. ver. 24.25.26.) I an≈øwere then, that the Mini≈øters are worthy of double honour, 1. Tim. 5. ver. 17. of ≈øingular love 1. The≈ø≈øa. 5. ver. 12.13. of great reverence, Heb. 13. ver. 17. yea of all humble dutie. yet I dare by no meanes make them Lords in the mini≈øterie, nor give to one of them authoritie above the other, for feare of this ≈øentence, which ≈øhall one day prevaile, Regnaverunt ≈øed non ex me, Ho≈øea. 8.4. They rule but not by me.

Quere, Whether the patrimonie of ancient time given to the Church, for the maintaining of learning, & the ≈øervice of god & to maintaine the e≈øtate eccle≈øia≈øticall as Bi≈øhops lands the lands pertaining to Cathedrall Churches, the gleebe lands and thithes, by order of law given to per≈øons and Vicars, are by right and gods word to be taken from them, or no.

An≈ø. Sic ea qua Cae≈øaris ≈øunt Cae≈øari e≈ø≈øe donanda, &c. is a perpetuall rule in things of the world, but yet with this caution unto every prince that feareth who is King of Kings: that fir≈øt there be provi≈øion ≈øufficient made for the mini≈øterie: then that the poore may have reliefe for their nece≈ø≈øitie. la≈øt of all, that Vniver≈øities and Schooles be well maintained, in ≈øuch number, as may
≈øtill ≈øupply the want in the mini≈øterie: without which con≈øiderations, the ≈øp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l of the church is mo≈øt unnaturall ≈øacriledge.

9. Quere. Whether the Mini≈øters of this Realme, of what calling ≈øo ever now in place, allowed by the lawes and order of this Realme, be lawful mini≈øters: and whether their admini≈øtration, and eccle≈øia≈øticall actions be lawfull or effectuall, or no.

An≈øwere. This ninth article, for ought that I ≈øee, is all one with the fourth 10. Quere. Wheither at a mariage it is not convenient to have a Communion and convenient for the new maried per≈øons to communicate: and at a funerall to have a ≈øermon, or no.

An≈øwere. I would have communions at ≈øuch times, as the church appointeth. In which dayes if there be a marriage, it is meete the parties there commucicate. For funerall ≈øermons, they may be u≈øed: yet if there bee in them any inconveniencie, that the Church be hurt or offended, being at an extraordinary time, they ≈øhould be left.
11. Quere. Whether it is lawfull for any man to preach, but he that is a pa≈øtout: and he onely to preach to his owne flocke or that any man may preach without a licence, or no.

An≈øwere. Of licen≈øes to preach. None may preach but a Pa≈øtour or Doctour, and being reque≈øted upon iu≈øt occa≈øion, he may preach out of his pari≈øh. But in his owne flock if he have no licen≈øe to preach, ≈øure he hath no licen≈øe to be a pa≈øier.

12. Quere. Whether it be better and more agreeable to the Gods word, and more convenient for the profit of Gods Church, that apre≈øcript order of Common prayer be u≈øed, or that every Mini≈øter pray publikely, as his own ≈øpirit ≈øhall direct him, or no.

An≈øwere. An ordinary prayer is very aece≈ø≈øary, that it may be made familier to the people: but as every pari≈øh ≈øhall have ≈øeverall occation, ≈øo it is nece≈ø≈øary that the Mini≈øter be wi≈øe to pray in the congregation, for the nece≈ø≈øaties of his people.
13. Quere Whether that Children of ≈øuch as be perfect papi≈øts, are to be bapti≈øed: and whether in≈øants are within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods covenant, and have faith, or no.

An≈øwere. If the parents be ob≈øtinate, and (as they are here tearmed) perfect papi≈øts, wanting nothing of all that ≈øpirituall wickedne≈ø≈øe and ≈øo accounted of the church, then their children are not to be admitted unto the Sacraments of the Church, Papi≈øh children not to be bapti≈øed. although we do not remove them from the election of God. But if they be not ca≈øt out of the church, we may admit their children not as haveing faith which commeth by hearing, but as being by grace in the covenat, I am their God and the God of their ≈øeede.
14. Quere. Whether any ecclefia≈øticall per≈øon, may have more eccle≈øia≈øticall liuings, than one, or no.

An≈øwere. As the nece≈øtatie of the man requireth, or the gi≈øts of God an
mo ‚Ä¢ e abundant, whereby thorowe great re≈øort they are the more charged: ≈øo they ought to be more liberally maintained. But as for one man to have many Per≈øonages, where he cannot po≈ø≈øibly be re≈øident, it is great wickednes And ≈øeeing Chri≈øt hath purcha≈øed his people with his owne bloud, who ≈øoever doth ≈øo enioy them, they con≈øider litle, the exhortation of Saint Paul: Of none ne≈øidents. Attend unto the flocke of Chri≈øt, of which the holy gho≈øt hath made you ever≈øeers, Act. 20. ver. 28. And therefore I humbly be≈øeech the high Court of Parliament to ≈øee it reformed;
15. Quere. Whether that one may be a Mini≈øter that hath no peculiar flock a≈ø≈øigned unto him, and whether an eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon may exerci≈øe a civile function, or no.

An≈øwere. A Mini≈øter can be no more without a charge, the ‚Ä¢ a King without a Kingdome, for exerci≈øing civill government, I ≈øay, Neme militans implicatur vitae negotiis, ut ei qui ≈øe in militiam detegit, placeat, 2 Timot. 2. ver. 4. And I am ≈øure what per≈øon ≈øoever ≈øeeketh after it, it is for want of that love, that ≈øhould mo≈øt abound: e≈øpecialy ≈øith we ≈øee our Saviour Chri≈øt refu≈øed to be a iudge, or any medler in divition of lands, though he were required, Luke. 12. ver. 13. yet will I not iudge any other, who upon ≈øpeciall occation in another copye it is, might for a time do good unto his Countrey by meanes of intreatie ≈øeeking to do good to his brother, doth take that charg al≈øo upon him.
16. Quere. Whether all the Commandements of God, and of the Apo≈øtles are needfull for ≈øalvation, or no.

An≈øwere. All the commandements given without limitt of per≈øon, place, or time, are nece≈ø≈øary for all men, ever to be ob≈øerved, as all other were, to tho≈øe to whom they were given. And as Chri≈øt was a Mini≈øter, not of earthly things, but of heavenly: ≈øo he gave no commandement but touching ≈øalvation. So that the breach of the lea≈øt of them (if it be imputed to us) hath a iu≈øt recompence of eternall death.
17. Quere. Whether the King of England hath authority over the Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øtate, and in Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters as well as over the civill ≈øtate or no?

An≈ø. Let every ≈øoule be ≈øubjest to the higher powers and as Chy≈øo≈øtome addeth, whether he be an Apo≈øtle, or Evangeli≈øt, or Prophet, or who≈øoever. This ≈øubjection is not again≈øt his calling. Princes have full authority over all Eccle≈øia≈øticall and civill per≈øons, and equally over both to puni≈øh the offenders or to give prai≈øe to the well doers. Onely this is the difference in the ≈øoveraignity over both. Fir≈øt the Common wealth can not be without the Magi≈øtrate, for it is noted a mo≈øt horrible confu≈øion when every man may doe what he li≈øt. Iud. 17. ver. 6. But if all Magi≈øtrates ≈øhould fall away from the Church, yet mu≈øt we ≈øtill hold this Article of our faith, I doe beleeve the Catholike Church: for Chri≈øt, and not: he Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate, is the life and head of it. Againe, in in the common wealth the Prince maketh or repealeth lawes, as hee thinketh the ≈øa≈øety of his e≈øtate and benefit of his people do mo≈øt require. But in the Church there is no law giver but Chri≈øt Je≈øus, James. 4. ver. 12. The Prince mu≈øt de≈øend the faith that he hath taught, and reward the good workes that he
hath commanded, and ≈øee what≈øoever hee ≈øhall e≈øtabli≈øh by authority, be „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øured by the rule that he hath given, 1. Cor. 10. ver. 23. and 1. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ 40. Philip. 4. ver. 9.

For God hath made the King, though he were as great as an Angell, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øervant in his Church: Princes ≈øervants in the church. in which re≈øpect the Prophet David pre≈øerreth it before all the glory of the World to be but a doore keeper in the hou≈øe of the Lor ‚Ä¢ , P≈øal. 84.10. And when the Lord him≈øelfe de≈øcribeth the excellent „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ mo≈øt noble Kings, he ≈øpeaketh thus to his Church: They ≈øhall wor≈øhip th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , with their faces bowed to the earth, and licke up the du≈øt under why feate, E≈øa. 49. ver. 23. So this conclu≈øion is plaine. The Prince ruleth in the „Äà‚óä„Äâ Wealth by law, and in the Church of God ≈øeeth that all be ruled of the Lord.

18. Quere. Whether the King of England be cheife governour under Chri≈øt, over the whole church and State Eccle≈øia≈øticall in this Realme, or „Äà‚óä„Äâ Member of the ≈øame, and whether the Church of England, may be e≈øtabli≈øhed without a Magi≈øtrate or no?
An≈ø. This is an≈øwered in the 17. Quere.

19. Quere. Whether the King of England be bound to ob≈øerve the judi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ all lawes of Mo≈øes, concerning the puni≈øhment and remitting of criminall o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ces, or no?

An≈ø. Of this we be mo≈øt ≈øure, that the Law of Mo≈øes unto the people of I≈øraell, was an ab≈øolute paterne of mo≈øt perfect juftice, ≈øo that all lawes ought to be made according to the equity of them, in ≈øuch proportion of ju≈øtice, a may be≈øt be applied to the countrey, where they are to be e≈øtabli≈øhed. For me to define of all particular cau≈øes, I dare not. Onely this I can ≈øay of that I read, becau≈øe God hath charged, Yee ≈øhall take no recompence for the life of the murtherer, Nomb. 35.32. And becau≈øe God, both by the law of nature, Gen. 38.24. Equitie of Mo≈øes law And by the Law of Mo≈øes hath jvdged the adulterer to dye, Levit. 20.10. I dare not avouch their pardon to be lawfull. Further, becau≈øe in the ≈øeat of Ju≈øtice, the man is but a Mini≈øter, and the judgement is the Lords, 2. Ch ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 19. ver. 6. Many learned men of our time have thought, that in ≈øo plaine and expre≈ø≈øe ca≈øes, no Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould ≈øpare the life of the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øour, but rather conte≈ø≈øe, as it is in Iob. cap. 34. ver. 31. It belongeth to the Lord to ≈øay I will pardon, I will not de≈øtroy. When God ≈øhall give me more under≈øtanding, I will ≈øpeake more boldly: in the meane ≈øea≈øon, I tru≈øt, I ≈øhall pray that God would give unto the Prince the ≈øpirit of Governement, to doe faithfully his ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
